To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: PORT ARTHUR.
div.p: The fall oi Port Arthur brings to a close the first greet phase of the war in the Par East, a phase that has been prolonged beyond all calculations by Stoessel’s obstinate and heroic resistance. The temptation to moralise is almost irresistible. The ignomi- nious end of the great squadron of the Pacific, the gradual crumbling of tho almost im- pregnable fortifications are in themselves both a sermon on the vanity of human wishes, and an illustration of what foresight and organisation can achieve when united to discipline, to oourage, and to patriotism. But the practical and strategical lemons to be learnednom this long siege ere of even greater interest to us as a maritime Power, and they deserve to be studied the more caretully be- cause of th' erroneous deductions to which the catastrophe of Port Arthur may give rise. Because the valour of the Kussian soldiers sad sailors has been in vain, and because the Russian Empire has suffered a humiliation to which the capture of Sebastopol was as nothing, it has been suggested by some authorities, end especially by the military correspondent of the Times, that fortifications are themselves a delusion and a snare, that the harbour of Port Arthur has been like a fatal magnet to the ships of the squadron, and that Kuropstkin should have begun his campaign by withdraw- ing every man and every movable gun from the Liao-tang Peninsula. In other words, Port Arthur is claimed to have been what Metz actually was, and what Ladysmith nearly became—a fatal entanglement, engulfing its own garrison, and finally compromising the forces outside oi it by robbing them of the power of initiative. Had Stdessel got the gar- rison away while the railway was unout, had Stark or Makaroff sailed off with the remnants of their fleet, the abandonment of Port Arthur itself; the enormous lost ot material, and the blow to Russian prestige, would have been more than compensated for by the freedom which it would have given to Kuropatkin from his first arrival on the scene.

Such an inference and such a teaching are, in our judgment, not only wrong, but highly dangerous, as tending to discredit the value of naval bases end garrisons to a maritime Power alike in peace and in war. They ignore the faot that the misfortunes of the Russian Fleet have been due solely and entirely to its own in- efficiency and to the incapacity of those who directed its movements. The ruin dates from the first night of the war, when the Japanese torpedo-boats were allowed to work their will, end it was oompleted by the reluotanoe and inability of the blockaded squadron to give battle to the adversary in open water. If the Russian Fleet had been bandied as the fleet of a first-class Power ought to be, and as every country has a right to expect from its naval officers, Port Arthur would have been an absolutely invaluable asset to Russia during the war, and the march of the Japanese armies on Manchuria would have been definitely delayed. A glance at the map shows that Port Arthur is an ideal “point d’appui" for any nation at war with Japan; and its importance can best be realised by the pro- digious sacrifices which the latter Power has undergone during the process of reducing it. Nor does it seem to be realised how much the prolongation of the siege has actually affected the course of the campaign ; to say nothing of the fearful loss of men, which will be felt more and more as the war drags, it deprived the Japanese of the superiority in numbers which would have turned the battle of Liao-yang into another Leipaic. And it has so absolutely absorbed the energies of Admiral Togo that he has been unable-to spare a single ship from his fleet of observation, even when the cruisers of Skrydloff were ravaging in the home waters of Japan. Had the Baltic Fleet been able to sail in the early summer, as Captain Mahan anticipated, the Japanese com- mander would have found himself in the presence of a dilemma which might well have proved fatal.

Indeed, the supreme importance of a well- fortified and well-garrisoned naval base has never been so dearly indicated, unless we go beck to the siege of Gibraltar in 1779-83. And the conclusion to ourselves ought to be irresistible. Our own naval bases, to say nothing of minor ooaling stations, are scattered over every see, and their retention at all ooists is the prioe of our existence as a naval Power. Gibraltar, Malta, Siqaimanlt, Halifax, Ber- muda, Singapore, Houg Kong, not to mention others, have each their own port to play in any scheme of Imperial defence. They do not all require the same sort of protection. Ber- muda, for instanoe, surrounded by its shoal water, and guarded by its mine-fields, needs a garrison rather then big guns. Halifax, with its rampart of the Atlantic surges, is practio- ally immune from a torpedo flotilla. But they all have to be defended, if we are to retain the power of sending our fleets securely from one part of the globe to another, and it is essential that, one and all, they must be able to guard themselves and their priceless stores of coal and material without dependence on the Fleet.

div.head: PORT ARTHUR FALLS. SUUKENDER OF GARRISON HOSTILITIES SUSPENDED. SHIPS BLOWN UP TOKIO REJOICINGS. MIKADO’S TRIBUTE TO STOESSEL.
div.p: Tokio, January 2.
General Nogi reports that he has received a letter from General Stoessel relating to tho surrender of the fortress. Tho Japanese stormed and captured Wantai Fort yesterday.
(Reuter.)
Tokio, January 2.

It is understood that hostilities at Port Arthur are suspended to-day, and the Russian and Japanese Chiefs of the Staff are to meet at noon at Shunshiying, in order to discuss the question of the surrender.
General Stoessel has written to General Nogi saying that any further resistance is useless.
The Mikado has telegraphed to General Nogi extolling General Stoessel and ordering that all military honors be shown to him.
(Reuter.)
Tokio, January 1.
General Stoessel has proposed to General Nogi, and the latter has accepted, to negotiate the surrender of the place.
(Havas.)
Chi-Fu, January 2
General Stoessel wrote yesterday to General Nogi saying that all further resistance was useless and asked to capitulate.
The Russian and Japanese negotiators met at noon and separated at 4 o'clock.
The Russians accept the conditions proposed.
Hostilities are suspended.
The Russians blew up several forts and ships in the morning.
(Havas)
Tokio, January 2.
Immense rejoicings are taking place in the town.
(Reuter)
Tokio, January 2.
The capitulation of Port Arthur is causing great enthusiasm.
The Mikado has ordered homage to be paid to General Stoessel.
(Havas)
Tokio, January 2.

General Nogi informed General Stoessel that he agreed to appoint negotiators provided that the commissioners on both sides have full powers to sign an immediate capitulation. Meanwhile, hostilities have been suspended.
(Later). The negotiations lasted from noon until 4.30 p.m. Arrangements have been con- cluded to sign an act of capitulation. The Japanese terms have been accepted.
(Reuter.)

div.head: AWFUL CONDITION OP THE TOWN.
div.p: Chi-Fu, January 2.
(Midnight). The “Retvisan," the “Pol- tava,” and the “ Pallada " caught fire at Port Arthur in the morning; they were still burning during the afternoon. Tho Russians blew up the " Sevastopol.”

The Russian officers state there are 15,000 sick and wounded at Port Arthur. Many soldiers are lying in the streets, as the hospitals have been shattered by the shells. The garrison numbers 5,000, most of whom are convalescents.
(Reuter.)

div.head: RUSSIAN SHIPS AT CHI-FU.
div.p: Chi-Fu, January 2.
Four Russian destroyers and a launch enter- ed the harbour. A bundle of despatches was taken ashore.
(Reuter.)
Chi-Fu, January 2.
Three large Japanese destroyers have entered the harbour.
(Reuter.)
Chi-Fu, January 2.
The Russian destroyers have disarmed, and the Japanese have consequently left the harbour.
(Reuter.)
Tsinqtau, January 2.
Two Russian destroyers and a merchantman with 800 soldiers have reached here.
(Reuter.)

div.head: OPINION ON THE PALL
div.p: London, January 2.

The concensus of opinion in diplomatic circles is that the fall of Port Arthur will only be a fresh incentive to renew the struggle more ' vigorously. Russia will not spare any efforts to recapture it, or compel its submission in- directly. The only reservation in this opinion is the internal condition of Russia, which is the dominant factor of the situation. (R.)

Amateur Theatricals.—The performance in Cairo of “The Pirates of Penzance” has been postponed, owing to the temporary absence of Lieut. Franklin, the musical director, in Khar- toum-. It will now probably take place about the third week in February. The respite is ap- preciated by the members of the troupe, as it was felt that the time allotted to the rehear- sals in the first instance was somewhat short. The delay will afford Major Delavoye more scope for the development of stage effects, and the performance will thus be as finished from a dramatic as from a musical point of view—a requirement not always sufficiently considered in the representation of comic operas by amateurs.

div.head: THE POSTMASTER GENERAL.
div.p: We are officially authorised to state that the announcement made to-day by a Cairo morning paper “on very good authority" that Saba Pa- sha, the Postmaster General, had tendered his resignation, is absolutely without any founda- tion whatsoever.

div.head: IMPORTANT APPOINTMENT.
div.p: We learn that Dr. W. St. C. Symmers, professor of pathology and bacteriology at the school of Medicine at Kasr-el-Aini, is about to leave Egypt to take up an important appointment in pathology at Belfast. Tbs Egyptian Government will feel the loss of a valuable servant, for Dr. Symmers, daring his sojourn in this country, has established for Himself a well-earned reputation as a scientific worker of great capacity and thoroughness. For his work at the Serum Institute for bovine typhus at Abbassieh the country owes him a special debt of gratitude. H.H. the Khedive has already testified his appreciation of Dr. Symmers' services in this connection by presenting him with a handsome set of diamond solitaires. Dr. Symmers' many friends in Egypt will boar of his approaching departure with regret.

div.head: ASSIOUT TRAINING COLLEGE.
div.p: The event of the Fall semester closing exercises of Assiout Training College was the contest between the Forum and Kiddonian Literary Societies. The representatives of the two societies, elected some months ago, contest- ed for honors in declamation, oration, and debate. The Kiddonian society won the oration and the debate, giving them five points out of six. The subjects of the two orations were “The Power of Oratory" and “Woman’s Power and Influence." 'The question for debate was “Resolved, that a final victory for Japan would be more beneficial to the world than a final victory for Russia.”

A feature of the occasion was the music, vocal and instrumental, furnished by local talent, assisted by Miss Dysart of Cairo. The singing of the college glee club was thoroughly enjoyed by all, and showed a great advance over anything the club has given in public heretofore.

A large number of the English-speaking community of Assiout were present,as the exercises were all in English. Every one was ready to congratulate the two societies and the college upon the great improvement in composition and style and delivery which was shown by the contest, since the orations and debate were entirely original productions by the students, with practically no changes made by the teachers. The two societies meet regularly each week, the results of careful drill and experience were quite manifest.

The college has enjoyed a very prosperous session, with an attendance of 550 students. A large new dining- room is being erected for the better accommodation of the boarding department. The staff of instructors now numbers twenty-three regular teachers, even of whom are Americans. A valuable addition to the corps was made this Fall, in the college savings secured Miss Strutters, recently of Boston, for instruction in art and penmanship, and Miss Moore, of Pennsylvania, as matron.

div.head: EGYPT’S TRADE.
NOVEMBER RETURNS.
div.p: The imports during the month kept up their usual rate of increase, which has been such a noticeable featereof this year’s customs returns. During November there was an increase of L.K. 794,898 over the figures for the cor- responding month lest year. Last November the imports amounted to L.E. 2,447,129, as against LE 1,653,231 in November, 1903. If December's imports showed a similar power of expansion the total imports for the year will show an increase of close upon L.R 4,000,000 over last year. Up to the end of November the imports amounted to L.R 18,140,838, as against L.R 15,038,399, an increase of LE. 8,107,439. The total exports during these eleven months amount to L.E. 18,201,952, an increase of L.R 1,705,341 over and above the figures for the corresponding period in 1903. The exports for November amounted to L.E. 8,666,967, a decrease of Li 884,857 on November lest year. This falling off is mainly to cotton exports, which decreased to value to the extent of LE 284,589, and cotton seed exports, which decreased by LE 76,482 com- pared with the figures for the previous November.

div.head: EGYPTIAN GOLD DEMAND.
div.p: The Statist understands that the Egyptian demand for gold is practically satisfied, which is entirely contrary to the general anticipa- tion. For some years past Egypt has been taking larger and larger amounts, and has been sending back less and less. It was gene- rally supposed that she would do the same this past year. As a matter of fact, she has taken exceptionally little.

The general explanation given is that Egyptian capitalists have been buying Egyp- tian bonds and Egyptian securities of all sorts in the London market upon a very large scale—upon so large a scale, in fact, that to all intents and purposes their purchases have counterbalanced the amount due to Egypt on account of her exports.

If the explanation be correct, it is interest- ing from two points of view: firstly, from the evidence it affords of the growth of wealth in Egypt. In all countries which have debts held in large amounts abroad, the natives begin to buy back those debts as soon as they advance in prosperity. Egypt, apparently, is doing this now. In the second place, it relieves the London market from one drain for gold. True, gold shipments after the turn of the year will not cause as much inconvenience as they would have caused during the past two or three months. Still it is well that the demand for the metal for abroad should decline.

div.head: THE TAWIL FAILURE
div.p: It has been decided to have a liquidation “a l'amiable” to the case of the failure of Mr. Selim TawiL Messrs. Gorrs, Sofio, and Deb- bane have been appointed liquidators.

It is estimated that the assets of Mr. Selim Tawil amount to LE 750,000 and the liabi- lities to LE 700,000. Even if this estimate is not correct it is thought that the liabilities will be sufficiently covered or even at the lowest estimate a dividend of 90 per cent, will be declared.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE. “ADRIANA LECOUVREUR.”
div.p: There was a large house at the Zizinia on Saturday and again last night to witness the performance of Maestro Cilea’s new opera, which met with a huge success. Signs. Angelica Pandolfini's interpretation of the title role was one deserving of the highest commendation. Her singing and acting were imbued with a great degree of originality and intelligence, and her rendering of the death scene was admir- able. Signa. A. Pandolfinl was ably supported by Sig. Bravi, who mde an excellent Count de Saxe. Tho baritone Nani, in the role of Michonnet, also scored a distinct success. Sig. Galetti-Gianoli, as Prince de Bouillon, Signi. Sals, Foglia, and Rossini were also at their best. The "mise en scene” was as good as ever and the orchestra to fine form.

div.head: “STRIKE" AT THE VERDI DEPARTURE OF THE ARTISTES.
div.p: The strike of the artistes of the Verdi Theatre, Cairo, has terminated to a most un- satisfactory manner the majority of the com- pany having announced their determination to return to Italy as soon as possible and having refused to accept the modified terms offered by the management. In our opinion, they have had every reason to feel aggrieved at their treatment both by the direction and the Cairo public. The company was a vary strong one, containing artistes of really superior quality to any we have recently heard at the Khedivial Opera House, but none the less they failed almost entirely to attract the steady attendance of the music loving public. Certain performances drew large audiences, but in the main the results were disappointing to the extreme.

We attribute this to part to the want of sufficient advertisement, and to the methods of the ticket-office, which were not always as courteous as might be wished, but the blame lies mainly on the public, who were very ready to applaud a performance given last night for the benefit of the artistes who are leaving Egypt, bot never gave them that continued support which would have made their departure unnecessary. Last night's per- formance was very successful. It consisted of the 3rd act of Aida, which was excellently perform- ed, acts from Traviata and Trovatore, the Danza delle Ore from Gioconda, and the fourth act of Otello. The artistes were all at their best and we must again express our regret at the debacle so excellent a company.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL AGRICULTURAL SOCIETY
div.p: The following correspondence passed between the Minister of Finance and the President of the Khedivial Agricultural Society with regard to the new constitution of the latter;-

Sir,—Since the formation, to 1898, of the Khedivial Agricultural Society, in which the Government took an active part, the interest shown by all classes of the community to the agricultural development of the country has largely increased. The various measures adopt- ed by the society—such as the organization of shows, the distribution of seed and manure, and the publicity given to kindred subjects through the medium of the Society's journal- have given a stimulus to all matters relating to the cultivation of the soil. Egypt being essentially an agricultural country, the general welfare of the cultivator most always be an object of the utmost solicitude to the Govern- ment, which during recent years has continued to aid the Society both financially and otherwise.

From time to time, the desirability of creat- ing a Ministry of Agriculture has been urged, but the Government is of opinion that, for the present at all events, greater benefits will result from an extension of the work of the Society on certain lines. The principal defect in the past has lain to the fact that the central administration of the Society and the culti- vators were not in touch. In considering any new scheme of development, this point is one which should receive serious attention.

After a careful study of the existing Sta- tutes of the Society, the Government has drafted, for the consideration of members, s series of revised Statutes of which I have the honor to enclose a copy. This document will be found to indicate generally the changes which, in the opinion of the Government, it is advisable to introduce into the organization of the Society.

It is suggested that, to accordance with Article 21 of the present Statutes, a gene- ral meeting of members of the Society should be convoked, and that the proposed changes should be submitted to them for approval. Should the Statutes be adopted either to their entirety or with such modifications as the So- ciety may consider desirable and as the Go- vernment may approve, the Government is prepared to still further increase the annual subvention now granted to the Society, to order that they may be put into force.

It is proposed that the Moudirieh Delega- tions to which reference is made to Articles 13, 14 and 15 of the amended Statutes, should be substituted for those now existing in the Moudirieh towns of Gharbieh, Sharkia and Minia. Competent Secretaries for other Moudiriehs are not at present available, but as opportunities occur a gradual extension will be made to this direction, and the Govern- ment will, if necessary, consider the advisability of proportionately increasing the subvention. In the meantime, the society may engage students who have obtained their diplomas from the School of Agriculture: and these gentlemen, being placed on the Society’s experi- mental farms, and allowed to participate in the general work, will, in the course of a year or so, become competent to act as Secretaries to additional Moudirieh Delegations.

The extension thus given to the work of ths society will necessitate the appointment of an assistant to the present Secretary, as well as that of a paid Accountant in the office. To meet this increase of expenditure, as well as to provide for the three Moudirieh Delegations to which allusion is made above, the Govern- ment is prepared to grant a sum of LE 3,000 annually to addition to the subvention now accorded.

The question of the establishment of a Statistical bureau, for the collection of infor- motion relating to crop areas and general agricultural returns, to which the Society is greatly interested, is at present occupying the attention of the Government
The Government will be glad to learn in due course the result of tho deliberations or mem- bers, in order that the proposed changes, if adopted, may be put into force from January 1st, 1905.

I am to add that the Government would view with pleasure the election of Your High- ness as President of the Society and also of the Executive and General Committees ; of HH. Prince Ibrahim Pasha Hilmy and of H.E. Riaz Pasha as Vice-Presidents of the General Com- mittee ; of H.E. Chawarby Pasha and Mr. Gib- son as Vice-Presidents, and of Mr. Carey as Assistant Vice-President of the Executive Com- mittee. The Government would suggest the nomination of Mr. G. P. Fosden, the present Secretary of the society, as Secretary General
I have the honour to be, etc signed: Ahmed Mazloum, Minister of Finance.
(Translation).
Excellency,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 841, dated 23rd November, 1904, containing the changes which the Go- vernment deems advisable to introduce into the Administration of the Society. This letter, together with the proposed new Statutes of the Society which accompanied it, formed the subject of deliberation at a meeting of our General Committee held under my presidency on December 3rd last The changes proposed were received with great satisfaction by the Society, and the Statutes, with the exception of one or two minor changes which the society thinks will render them more perfect, and which, under cover and separate letter I have communicated to your Excellency for considera- tion by the Government, were unanimously adopted.

In accordance with the request contained to your Excellency’s letter, and in conformity with Art 21 of the existing Statutes of the Society, a general meeting of members was held on December 6th last at which the members cordially approved of the changes proposed and confirmed the decisions taken by the Com- mittee of the Society at its meeting of the 3rd inst. The society feels assured that the steps taken by the government to increase its sphere of usefulness will result in a much greater interest being taken in its work by agricultur- its generally. Through the medium of the proposed Moudirieh Delegations, the steps taken by the society to aid cultivators in a practical manner will receive greater publicity and the society feels assured that greater ad- vantage will be taken of them.

The members of the society view with great pleasure the continued interest which the Government takes in its work, and it is a great pleasure for me, as president of the society, to be the interpreter of the cordial votes and thanks which were passed at the meetings over which I had the honor to preside.
I have the honor to be, etc.
signed: Huessin Kamri, President.
His excellency, The Minister of Finance, Cairo.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Judge Halton is staying at the Mena House Hotel.

Over 100 tourists have arrived et Shep- heard’s Hotel from the North German Lloyd SS. "Friedrich der Grosse." Among them we notice Comte de Perigord, Hon. Mrs. Sackville West, Freiherr von Bernewits, Commerrienrath Schott and family, Mr. and Mrs. Clay Evans, Mr. R. A. Pinkerton and family, Mr. Jul. Rothschild, Mr. Luis de Sommers and family, Baron de la Huerta, Mr. J. P. Frank and Mrs. E R Frank, Mr. Lionel Sutro and family, Mr. and Mrs A. Frappier, Mr. and Mrs.L Donnel, etc.
Captain E. M. K. Parsons, Governor Mili- tary Prison, Cairo, left for Khartoum on San- day on inspection duty.
Mr. McPherson Grant, agent at Alexandria for the Sudan Government Railways, is re- turning with his bride to Egypt on the 15th inst.

Mr. Arthur Fowler, of the firm of John Fowler & Co. of Leeds, who paid a visit to Egypt last month, has arrived at Railhead on the Abyssinian Railway. He is on his way to pay a visit to the Emperor Menelik to order to advise the Negus on the subject of traction engines. Menelik had previously given this firm an order for a dozen traction engines.
The appointments of Ravenscroft Bey, Mr. H. M. Anthony, Mr. Clowes, and Mr. Mac- donald are officially confirmed.
Lieut A. C. K. Magill, 2nd Royal Innis- killing Fusiliers, has been appointed District Signalling Officer, Egypt
Mr. Richmond, Inspector of Public Build- ings, has been appointed a member of the Superior Provincial Council, Ministry of the Interior.
We are requested to state that Mr. Methold, and not Judge Ingle Joyce, was the barrister in whose chambers Judge Vaux read at Lincoln’s Inn.

The following passengers left Cairo by the "Hotasoo" on Friday for the Nile trip:— Mr. and Mrs. Rankine, Mr. and Mrs. C. Guerin, Miss Milner, Miss Handley, Mr. and Mrs. H. Morel Journal. The Best Remedy for A Heavy Cold

div.head: MANSOURAH
S.P. C.A. BAZAAR.
(From a Couuspondbht.)
div.p: A branch of the S. P. C. A. waa started in Mansourah about three months ago. Over 70 horses having benefited from it during that period, it waa thought better that the society should build stables of their own. A bazaar was insdtnted by the Moudir of Dakfthlinh and Mr. Murdoch to provide the necessary funds. By the Unrinn** ol the Russian Consul and Mrs. Orris, this bazaar waa held on December 30 in the beautilul Maison Orris. The grnuuda wopj also thrown open and looked lovely with Bowers and orange trees in full fruit; the drive was magnifiuently decorated with Turkish flags, Venetian masts draped in red and white, and garlands of iruit and ever- greens. A native band was in attendance to herald tho approach of visitors.

In tho drawing-room there were threo large stalls very prettily decorated with the Turkish colours. At No. 1 Mrs. Murdoch and Mme Diab presided, assisted by Miss. Warner. Mu. 2 was in charge ot Mrs. Carr, Mme. Bouchanti, and Mine. Kyutlywkos, assisted by Miss Smith. Miss bald superintended the large bran pie. Mrs. Smith gave an excellent tea tu the delightful colonnade in trout ot the house, and she was assisted by Miss Spring

Lotteries formed one ot the special features of the bazaar. Tue prizes, mauy of which were solid silver, were all on view on the 3rd stall. Amongst other things on the stalls we noticed some handsome bronzes, cushions, hand- painted glass vases, ducks, tea- cloths, and a large assortment of dulls dressed in various costumes.

Mrs. Carr gave a very good gnunaphone entertainment in the dining-room to the harem ladies in the morning, and Mr. Carr took her place in the alternuou. We noticed amongst the native ladies who visited the bazaar in the morning Sitt Bamba Goriah, Sitt Hafiz and Sitt Choucky, besides Mme. Greis and Mlle. Greis.

Shortly after two o’dock the Moudir an- nounced the bazaar open in a felicitous speech, and told those present he hoped their purses would be so light when they left that they would not have sufficient money left to hire a carriage to go home. Amongst those present were Mr. and Mrs. Murdoch, the latter in a charming pink gown trimmed with black lace and a black and white toque; Mrs. and Miss Smith, Mr. and Mrs. Carr, Mme. Diab, in a tailor made coat and skirt; Mme. Kyndynikos, Mme. Bouchaiiti,the Rev. and Mrs. Firmmger, he latter in a pretty grey voile dress ; Miss Warner, who was in white ertpo de Chine, and Miss Gabald, in grey voile; Dr. Ekius, Mr.Moberley, Miss Orris, Mr. Hopkins, Mr. Templeton, Mr. Morrison, and others.

The sales commenced in earnest and soon the stalU began to look less crowded. In the evening an auction of all the articles that were left was most ably undertaken by Mr. Sarny, and we believo about £230 will be handed to the treasurer of the S.P.C.A.
Mrs. Murdoch desires to take this oppor- tunity of thanking all those friends who were kind enough to send contributions to the bazaar, and to help make it the great suooeaa it has been.

div.head: VANDALISM AT CANOPUS.
WHO IS RESPONSIBLE ?
div.p: Some mouths ago an important arehmological discovery was made at Aboukir, on' the site of what is popularly supposed to be that of tho ancient Canopus, when tho temple of Aniooi Aphrodite, which Ptolemy Phiedelphus erected at tho Zephirion fore- lard, was discovered. It has been a subject of discussion as to whother tho temple was erected in honor of Senpia or of Aphrodite, but at any rate it it a discovery of great interest and importance, and the remains of the temple that were found in the spring were considerable, while the mosaic pavements were most artistic and elaborate. We announced in May that negotiation* had begun betwoen the Alexandria Arcboological Society and Prinoo Omar Pasha Touasouu, on whose lauds the ruins are situated, and that it was expected that systematic researches would he taken b baud shortly. The Alexandria Museum autho- rities at tho same time issued a note on the temple wherein it waa stated that

“Le mfodnatisine du prince, son amour pour U science et pour U dignitd d’Alexandria aont de ahros garanuos qu'tl fmilitem par tout moyens les loutile uccessaires qui pourraieut donner d'importauts niauhate, si elies.sont scieutifiquement dirige.”

But, as is usually the case in Egypt, the official authorities did absolutely nothing. The Museum authorities and the members ol that moribund institution, the Alexandria Archeological Society, wore evidently at that time far more concerned in making plans as to their summer holidays in Europe, than in taking any thought as to the wonderful disoovery of the long-hidden temple. When we visited the temple last May, the exposed por- tions of the newly-feond sanctuary ot Aphro- dite were most interesting. The mosaic pave- ments were in an excellent state of preserva- tion and tho charming designs were as fresh then, alter two thousand yean, as they were wheu Canopus was still the most renowned watering place b the Eastern Mediterranean, seooud only to Bain b all the ancient world.

Among the mauy other newly-discovered sites was a catacomb, which was very like the catacomb in the Antoniadis Garden at Alex- andria. Access to it was by a flight of steps and it was b a very fair state ot preservation. The whole neighbourhood ot tho temple afforded a uuique held lor excavations, oud by the judi- cious ciuploymeut of a small sum ot money it ouuld have been tuaue one of tho “show places’’ ot Alexandria. But since it was discovered nothing has been done, and instead of endea- vouring to preserve these relics of the past, somebody has been guilty ot permitting acts ot tho grossest vandalism. We visited the site ol the temple of Anehud Aphrodite, or the sanc- tuary of Senpia, on Saturday lost, and the contrast between the state of the remains then- and b last May was appalling, for the tew months that had elapsed since our lorrner visit had sufficed to work irreparable ruin. Tho rains had brought down a consi- derable amount of sedimentary deposit upon the moeaio pavements, mauy ot which are utterly obliterated, while their coffipuneui ports have been loosened or destroyed by exposure to the damp and winter weather. Two spots b the immediate neighbourhood of the temple, where in May last there were some interesting remains, had evidently been utilised as quarries, and stacks of stone showed that these relics of antiquity hod been used for obtaining buildbg material. We searched lor any signs of the beaulifqj catacombs, but on tho site we found that all traces had been destroyed, and a gang ot workmen were busily employed in rumiug every evi- dence of antiquity which was a likely object for using for buildbg.

Does the site belong to Prince Omar Pasha Tousaoun, and are these workmen, who were so employed, under his Highness's orders and b his payt What, then, do the authorities of the Alexandria Museum mean by referring to “le Mecenatisme du Prince,” when Prince Dinar can permit such vandalism on hi* estate. It ■ is absurd to appeal to the Alexandria Archeological 8odety, for it lacks energy and initiative, and although some of its members are amiable dilletaute, it is destitute of any “go." What can be thought of an archioological society that has never movod a finger to excavate or protect the unique remains at tho ancient Tapcsiris, which are only a few miles from Alexandria f Is it more likely that it will exert itself to protect the vestiges of Canopus from destruction t The present condition of the rubs on the old Zephirion foreland as compared with their state last May is sufficient proof of the inutility of the society.

About a fortnight ago the society decided “to do something” b reference to the discoveries at Canopus with a view to transporting the relice of the temple to Alexandria. On the instigation of Poilay Bey, the Wekil of Prince Omar Pasha Tousaoun, the matter was brought to the notice of the society, and it was do cided by them that an estimate should be made as to the expenses. But irreparable damage has been done, and while the society is framing estimates the remains are being destroyed as fast as possible.

div.head: THE SUEZ CANAL.
M. BONNETS STATEMENTS.
REPLY BY SIR THEODORE ANGIER.
( From The Standard. )
div.p: Keen interest continues to be taken b the suggestion that a competing waterway should be cut through tho Isthmus ot Suez. 'There is no doubt that the agitation for lower rate*, especially for cargo steamers, has a consider- able becking. The whole matter is one which is boing very froely discussed both at Uoyd'a and tho Baltic, the centre of the shipping business. The interview which our Paris Dor respondent had with M. Bonnet was read yes- terday with interest.

Referring to a statement by one of the English directors of the Suez Canal, Sir Theodore Angier said to a Press representa- tive—"He is quite oorrect b what he says, except iu stating that shipowners sought to evade regulations. Shipowners built ships with increased superstructures because it im- proved the type ot ship b safety and the comfort of tho crews. In these superstructure* cargo is sometimes carriedJ and when this is the cose owners are and always have been agreed that dues are fairly and properly charged. But tho Board suddenly made a change b their custom hitherto, and now insist on charging dues on the tonnage of these spaces wheu no cargo is carried b tkem. This is the uulaitness complained of as far as tonnage is oouoerned, besides the breach of the 1883 agreement, and the lax servioe of the British shipowners on the Board."

Speaking ot the former agitation. Sir Theo- dore said .—“It is quite true that no conces- sion was actually made, but an under*tandbg existed ; and, with regard to the monopolist character of the Suez Canal Concession, the best lawyers of the day gave their opinion that it did not exist. Mr. Gladstone's view of the subject was entirely contradicted. The director you quote is quite oorrect, so far as ho goes ; but no atientiuu is paid to the fact that the present policy i* a reversal ot the previous ono. Because cargo has once been carried, we are uow to pay tor it always. It is most unfair that shipowners should be mulcted b this way simply because they have improved their vessels.

"I go further,” went on Sir Theodore," and declare that the original bases on which the dues are charged were must unfair. 'These terms were never blended to nerve lor all time, lor oUauges were bouud to supervene owing to variatiuus ui trade, customs, and other matters. VV by should they want a special agreement ou the Canal wheu b no otoer institution of a similar kind is it required 1 There are thous- ands and thousands of ducks, riven, quay* and too like, which gob their revenue by taxing the tonnage of ships, and nearly the whole of these enterprises have agreed to take a fair registry, that of Lloyd's. In the laoe of that moss ol due leviere, the Suez Canal people aay, ‘We are monopolists ; we will do what we like.' They liave aggravated the position after we agreed to this unlair arrangement, and let it go on lor years, by, now that deok spaces have oume into vogue, chargbg for them when ouce used for cargo. It is must unsatisfactory that the British directors should have agreed to the change without communicating with us.

“M. Bonnet talks about the agreement, but it was one duly accepted. 1 made no sugges- tion that I was going to do anything, but I •want to make dear the dissatisfaction ot the British shipowner, and 1 think the points 1 brought out are reasonable—namely, the way we are treated with regard to tonnage dues, the way we are treated by the British repre- sentatives on tho Board, and the breach of the London agreement of 1883 by the Company paying over 35 per cent, dividend with a rate at 8.50 francs per ton. 'The response we got to our representations to tho Directors waa far from courteous, and practically amounted to *Tako what you have got or leave it' But we are not tho helpless creatures the Canal people think we are, and 1 believe that, even by their own action, they are bringing about their own defeat Tho result will bo that oxen if no other canal is out shipowners will alter their style of vessel, and will build those which, while they oould not pay going through the Canal, will do so if sent round the Cape, 1 coonotconceive that any Government would object to a seooud canal, for, by increasing the fecilities for traffic, it would be all in the in- terests of trade."

div.head: HAMBURG-AMERICAN LINE AND THE CANAL.
div.p: The London Earning Standard says that the directors of the Hamburg-American Com- pany have issued a statement explaining their views b regard to the question of a seoond Suez Canal.

In this statement, Herr Baffin and hia ool- leagues reiterate and emphasise the accusations of mismanagement already brought against the Sues Canal Company. They mention in parti- cular the refusal of the oompany to devote the surplus of dividends exceeding 25 per oent, to a reduction of the Canal dues, as required by the London programme of 1883, and the enforcement of oertab antiquated regula- tion* adopted at the Constantinople Con- ference of 1878, relating to the dues for spaces on deck available for cargo.
The statement of the Hamburg-American Company, which may be regarded as the manifesto of the opposition to the Suez Canal Company, concludes-

“ The management of the Suez Canal is sneb that it exasperates the whole shipping world. If the present agitation b favor of a seoond canal result* b the redaction of the toll* ol the existing canal, the shipping trade with the Par East will be greatly Oeilitated. After .the ooooluloa of the war between Russia and Japan there will be gnat opportunities for developing the trade with Par Eastern coun- tries.

If; however, the Suez Canal oontbuea to be managed as at present, both Russia, with the TranaBiborian Railway (the efficiency of which has been greatly increased by the war), and America, with her direct sea route, will be far more fevonbly situated than tho European countries whose way lice through the canal."
